Or everything.<br/><br/>Schedule a Demo<br/><br/>USE CASES<br/><br/>Headless CMSEnterprise App BuilderHeadless E-CommerceDigital Asset Management<br/><br/>FEATURES<br/><br/>Multi-TenancyWhite LabelLocalizationAccess ControlAuth<br/><br/>CASE STUDIES<br/><br/>#### See what others are building with Payload.<br/><br/>Browse Case Studies<br/><br/>Why Payload<br/><br/>Build tomorrow‚Äôs web with a modern solution you truly own.<br/><br/>PAYLOAD IS FOR<br/><br/>DevelopersMarketing teamsEnterprise companiesAgencies & Consultancies<br/><br/>COMPARE PAYLOAD<br/><br/>Payload vs WordPressPayload vs ContentfulPayload vs SanityPayload vs StrapiPayload vs Directus<br/><br/>AGENCY TESTIMONIAL<br/><br/>#### "Payload has transformed the way our clients manage content. It's an indispensable tool for any modern agency."<br/><br/>Become a PartnerFind a Partner<br/><br/>Developers<br/><br/>Code-based nature means you can build on top of it to power anything.<br/><br/>Resources<br/><br/>DocumentationExamplesTemplatesGitHubReleasesBlogGuides & Tutorials<br/><br/>Community<br/><br/>RoadmapDiscordCommunity Help<br/><br/>Payload Cloud<br/><br/>#### Deploy your entire stack in one place with Payload Cloud.<br/><br/>LoginCloud Pricing<br/><br/>Enterprise<br/><br/>It‚Äôs time to take back your content infrastructure.<br/><br/>Schedule a Demo<br/><br/>Enterprise Features<br/><br/>SSOAI Auto-EmbeddingPublishing WorkflowsVisual EditorStatic A/B testingAI features<br/><br/>Customer Stories<br/><br/>MicrosoftASICSBlue OriginHello BelloTekton<br/><br/>Featured Customer Story<br/><br/>#### Microsoft chose Payload to tell the world about AI.<br/><br/>Read the case studyBrowse all<br/><br/>Docs<br/><br/>LoginGet Started<br/><br/>Search<br/><br/>Search<br/><br/># Collection Configs<br/><br/>A Collection is a group of records, called Documents, that all share a common schema. You can define as many Collections as your application needs. Each Document in a Collection is stored in the Database based on the Fields that you define, and automatically generates a Local API, REST API, and GraphQL API used to manage your Documents.<br/><br/>Collections are also used to achieve Authentication in Payload. By defining a Collection with `auth` options, that Collection receives additional operations to support user authentication.<br/><br/>Collections are the primary way to structure recurring data in your application, such as users, products, pages, posts, and other types of content that you might want to manage. Each Collection can have its own unique Access Control, Hooks, Admin Options, and more.<br/><br/>To define a Collection Config, use the `collection` property in your Payload Config:<br/><br/>1<br/><br/>import \{ buildConfig \} from 'payload'<br/><br/>2<br/><br/>3<br/><br/>export default buildConfig(\{<br/><br/>4<br/><br/>// ...<br/><br/>5<br/><br/> collections: \[<br/><br/>6<br/><br/>7<br/><br/>// Your Collections go here<br/><br/>8<br/><br/>\],<br/><br/>9<br/><br/>\})<br/><br/>**Tip:** If your Collection is only ever meant to contain a single Document, consider using a Global instead.<br/><br/>Config Options<br/><br/>It's often best practice to write your Collections in separate files and then import them into the main Payload Config.<br/><br/>Here is what a simple Collection Config might look like:<br/><br/>1<br/><br/>import type \{ CollectionConfig \} from 'payload'<br/><br/>2<br/><br/>3<br/><br/>export const Posts: CollectionConfig \= \{<br/><br/>4<br/><br/> slug: 'posts',<br/><br/>5<br/><br/> fields: \[<br/><br/>6<br/><br/>\{<br/><br/>7<br/><br/> name: 'title',<br/><br/>8<br/><br/> type: 'text',<br/><br/>9<br/><br/>\},<br/><br/>10<br/><br/>\],<br/><br/>11<br/><br/>\}<br/><br/>**Reminder:** For more complex examples, see the Templates and Examples directories in the Payload repository.<br/><br/>The following options are available:<br/><br/>\| Option             \| Description                                                                                                                                                                                                                      \|<br/>\| ------------------ \| -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- \|<br/>\| admin              \| The configuration options for the Admin Panel. [More details](#admin-options).                                                                                                                                                   \|<br/>\| access             \| Provide Access Control functions to define exactly who should be able to do what with Documents in this Collection. [More details](../access-control/collections).                                                               \|<br/>\| auth               \| Specify options if you would like this Collection to feature authentication. [More details](../authentication/overview).                                                                                                         \|<br/>\| custom             \| Extension point for adding custom data (e.g. for plugins)                                                                                                                                                                        \|<br/>\| disableDuplicate   \| When true, do not show the "Duplicate" button while editing documents within this Collection and prevent duplicate from all APIs.                                                                                                \|<br/>\| defaultSort        \| Pass a top-level field to sort by default in the Collection List View. Prefix the name of the field with a minus symbol ("-") to sort in descending order. Multiple fields can be specified by using a string array.             \|<br/>\| dbName             \| Custom table or Collection name depending on the Database Adapter. Auto-generated from slug if not defined.                                                                                                                      \|<br/>\| endpoints          \| Add custom routes to the REST API. Set to false to disable routes. [More details](../rest-api/overview#custom-endpoints).                                                                                                        \|<br/>\| fields \*          \| Array of field types that will determine the structure and functionality of the data stored within this Collection. [More details](../fields/overview).                                                                          \|<br/>\| graphQL            \| Manage GraphQL-related properties for this collection. [More](#graphql)                                                                                                                                                          \|<br/>\| hooks              \| Entry point for Hooks. [More details](../hooks/overview#collection-hooks).                                                                                                                                                       \|<br/>\| orderable          \| If true, enables custom ordering for the collection, and documents can be reordered via drag and drop. Uses [fractional indexing](https://observablehq.com/@dgreensp/implementing-fractional-indexing) for efficient reordering. \|<br/>\| labels             \| Singular and plural labels for use in identifying this Collection throughout Payload. Auto-generated from slug if not defined.                                                                                                   \|<br/>\| enableQueryPresets \| Enable query presets for this Collection. [More details](../query-presets/overview).                                                                                                                                             \|<br/>\| lockDocuments      \| Enables or disables document locking. By default, document locking is enabled. Set to an object to configure, or set to false to disable locking. [More details](../admin/locked-documents).                                     \|<br/>\| slug \*            \| Unique, URL-friendly string that will act as an identifier for this Collection.                                                                                                                                                  \|<br/>\| timestamps         \| Set to false to disable documents' automatically generated createdAt and updatedAt timestamps.                                                                                                                                   \|<br/>\| typescript         \| An object with property interface as the text used in schema generation. Auto-generated from slug if not defined.                                                                                                                \|<br/>\| upload             \| Specify options if you would like this Collection to support file uploads. For more, consult the [Uploads](../upload/overview) documentation.                                                                                    \|<br/>\| versions           \| Set to true to enable default options, or configure with object properties. [More details](../versions/overview#collection-config).                                                                                              \|<br/>\| defaultPopulate    \| Specify which fields to select when this Collection is populated from another document. [More Details](../queries/select#defaultpopulate-collection-config-property).                                                            \|<br/>\| indexes            \| Define compound indexes for this collection. This can be used to either speed up querying/sorting by 2 or more fields at the same time or to ensure uniqueness between several fields.                                           \|<br/>\| forceSelect        \| Specify which fields should be selected always, regardless of the select query which can be useful that the field exists for access control / hooks                                                                              \|<br/><br/>_\* An asterisk denotes that a property is required._<br/><br/>Fields<br/><br/>Fields define the schema of the Documents within a Collection. To learn more, go to the Fields documentation.<br/><br/>Access Control<br/><br/>Collection Access Control determines what a user can and cannot do with any given Document within a Collection. To learn more, go to the Access Control documentation.<br/><br/>Hooks<br/><br/>Collection Hooks allow you to tie into the lifecycle of your Documents so you can execute your own logic during specific events. To learn more, go to the Hooks documentation.<br/><br/>Admin Options<br/><br/>The behavior of Collections within the Admin Panel can be fully customized to fit the needs of your application. This includes grouping or hiding their navigation links, adding Custom Components, selecting which fields to display in the List View, and more.<br/><br/>To configure Admin Options for Collections, use the `admin` property in your Collection Config:<br/><br/>1<br/><br/>import type \{ CollectionConfig \} from 'payload'<br/><br/>2<br/><br/>3<br/><br/>export const MyCollection: CollectionConfig \= \{<br/><br/>4<br/><br/>// ...<br/><br/>5<br/><br/> admin: \{<br/><br/>6<br/><br/>7<br/><br/>// ...<br/><br/>8<br/><br/>\},<br/><br/>9<br/><br/>\}<br/><br/>The following options are available:<br/><br/>\| Option                     \| Description                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           \|<br/>\| -------------------------- \| ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- \|<br/>\| group                      \| Text or localization object used to group Collection and Global links in the admin navigation. Set to false to hide the link from the navigation while keeping its routes accessible.                                                                 \|<br/>\| hidden                     \| Set to true or a function, called with the current user, returning true to exclude this Collection from navigation and admin routing.                                                                                                                 \|<br/>\| hooks                      \| Admin-specific hooks for this Collection. [More details](../hooks/collections).                                                                                                                                                                       \|<br/>\| useAsTitle                 \| Specify a top-level field to use for a document title throughout the Admin Panel. If no field is defined, the ID of the document is used as the title. A field with virtual: true cannot be used as the title, unless it's linked to a relationship'. \|<br/>\| description                \| Text to display below the Collection label in the List View to give editors more information. Alternatively, you can use the admin.components.Description to render a React component. [More details](#custom-components).                            \|<br/>\| defaultColumns             \| Array of field names that correspond to which columns to show by default in this Collection's List View.                                                                                                                                              \|<br/>\| disableCopyToLocale        \| Disables the "Copy to Locale" button while editing documents within this Collection. Only applicable when localization is enabled.                                                                                                                    \|<br/>\| hideAPIURL                 \| Hides the "API URL" meta field while editing documents within this Collection.                                                                                                                                                                        \|<br/>\| enableRichTextLink         \| The [Rich Text](../fields/rich-text) field features a Link element which allows for users to automatically reference related documents within their rich text. Set to true by default.                                                                \|<br/>\| enableRichTextRelationship \| The [Rich Text](../fields/rich-text) field features a Relationship element which allows for users to automatically reference related documents within their rich text. Set to true by default.                                                        \|<br/>\| folders                    \| A boolean to enable folders for a given collection. Defaults to false. [More details](../folders/overview).                                                                                                                                           \|<br/>\| meta                       \| Page metadata overrides to apply to this Collection within the Admin Panel. [More details](../admin/metadata).                                                                                                                                        \|<br/>\| preview                    \| Function to generate preview URLs within the Admin Panel that can point to your app. [More details](../admin/preview).                                                                                                                                \|<br/>\| livePreview                \| Enable real-time editing for instant visual feedback of your front-end application. [More details](../live-preview/overview).                                                                                                                         \|<br/>\| components                 \| Swap in your own React components to be used within this Collection. [More details](#custom-components).                                                                                                                                              \|<br/>\| listSearchableFields       \| Specify which fields should be searched in the List search view. [More details](#list-searchable-fields).                                                                                                                                             \|<br/>\| pagination                 \| Set pagination-specific options for this Collection. [More details](#pagination).                                                                                                                                                                     \|<br/>\| baseListFilter             \| You can define a default base filter for this collection's List view, which will be merged into any filters that the user performs.                                                                                                                   \|<br/><br/>Custom Components<br/><br/>Collections can set their own Custom Components which only apply to Collection-specific UI within the Admin Panel. This includes elements such as the Save Button, or entire layouts such as the Edit View.<br/><br/>To override Collection Components, use the `admin.components` property in your Collection Config:<br/><br/>1<br/><br/>import type \{ CollectionConfig \} from 'payload'<br/><br/>2<br/><br/>3<br/><br/>export const MyCollection: CollectionConfig \= \{<br/><br/>4<br/><br/>// ...<br/><br/>5<br/><br/> admin: \{<br/><br/>6<br/><br/> components: \{<br/><br/>7<br/><br/>8<br/><br/>// ...<br/><br/>9<br/><br/>\},<br/><br/>10<br/><br/>\},<br/><br/>11<br/><br/>\}<br/><br/>The following options are available:<br/><br/>\| Option          \| Description                                                                                                                                                                      \|<br/>\| --------------- \| -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- \|<br/>\| afterList       \| An array of components to inject _after_ the built-in List View. [More details](../custom-components/list-view#afterlist).                                                       \|<br/>\| afterListTable  \| An array of components to inject _after_ the built-in List View's table. [More details](../custom-components/list-view#afterlisttable).                                          \|<br/>\| beforeList      \| An array of components to inject _before_ the built-in List View. [More details](../custom-components/list-view#beforelist).                                                     \|<br/>\| beforeListTable \| An array of components to inject _before_ the built-in List View's table. [More details](../custom-components/list-view#beforelisttable).                                        \|<br/>\| listMenuItems   \| An array of components to render within a menu next to the List Controls (after the Columns and Filters options)                                                                 \|<br/>\| Description     \| A component to render below the Collection label in the List View. An alternative to the admin.description property. [More details](../custom-components/list-view#description). \|<br/>\| edit            \| Override specific components within the Edit View. [More details](#edit-view-options).                                                                                           \|<br/>\| views           \| Override or create new views within the Admin Panel. [More details](../custom-components/custom-views).                                                                          \|<br/><br/>Edit View Options<br/><br/>1<br/><br/>import type \{ CollectionCOnfig \} from 'payload'<br/><br/>2<br/><br/>3<br/><br/>export const MyCollection: CollectionConfig \= \{<br/><br/>4<br/><br/>// ...<br/><br/>5<br/><br/> admin: \{<br/><br/>6<br/><br/> components: \{<br/><br/>7<br/><br/> edit: \{<br/><br/>8<br/><br/>9<br/><br/>// ...<br/><br/>10<br/><br/>\},<br/><br/>11<br/><br/>\},<br/><br/>12<br/><br/>\},<br/><br/>13<br/><br/>\}<br/><br/>The following options are available:<br/><br/>\| Option          \| Description                                                                                                                                                                                             \|<br/>\| --------------- \| ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- \|<br/>\| SaveButton      \| Replace the default Save Button within the Edit View. [Drafts](../versions/drafts) must be disabled. [More details](../custom-components/edit-view#savebutton).                                         \|<br/>\| SaveDraftButton \| Replace the default Save Draft Button within the Edit View. [Drafts](../versions/drafts) must be enabled and autosave must be disabled. [More details](../custom-components/edit-view#savedraftbutton). \|<br/>\| PublishButton   \| Replace the default Publish Button within the Edit View. [Drafts](../versions/drafts) must be enabled. [More details](../custom-components/edit-view#publishbutton).                                    \|<br/>\| PreviewButton   \| Replace the default Preview Button within the Edit View. [Preview](../admin/preview) must be enabled. [More details](../custom-components/edit-view#previewbutton).                                     \|<br/>\| Upload          \| Replace the default Upload component within the Edit View. [Upload](../upload/overview) must be enabled. [More details](../custom-components/edit-view#upload).                                         \|<br/><br/>**Note:** For details on how to build Custom Components, see Building Custom Components.<br/><br/>Pagination<br/><br/>All Collections receive their own List View which displays a paginated list of documents that can be sorted and filtered. The pagination behavior of the List View can be customized on a per-Collection basis, and uses the same Pagination API that Payload provides.<br/><br/>To configure pagination options, use the `admin.pagination` property in your Collection Config:<br/><br/>1<br/><br/>import type \{ CollectionConfig \} from 'payload'<br/><br/>2<br/><br/>3<br/><br/>export const Posts: CollectionConfig \= \{<br/><br/>4<br/><br/>// ...<br/><br/>5<br/><br/> admin: \{<br/><br/>6<br/><br/> pagination: \{<br/><br/>7<br/><br/> defaultLimit: 10,<br/><br/>8<br/><br/> limits: \[10, 20, 50\],<br/><br/>9<br/><br/>\},<br/><br/>10<br/><br/>\},<br/><br/>11<br/><br/>\}<br/><br/>The following options are available:<br/><br/>\| Option       \| Description                                                                                         \|<br/>\| ------------ \| --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- \|<br/>\| defaultLimit \| Integer that specifies the default per-page limit that should be used. Defaults to 10\.             \|<br/>\| limits       \| Provide an array of integers to use as per-page options for admins to choose from in the List View. \|<br/><br/>List Searchable Fields<br/><br/>In the List View, there is a "search" box that allows you to quickly find a document through a simple text search. By default, it searches on the ID field. If defined, the `admin.useAsTitle` field is used. Or, you can explicitly define which fields to search based on the needs of your application.<br/><br/>To define which fields should be searched, use the `admin.listSearchableFields` property in your Collection Config:<br/><br/>1<br/><br/>import type \{ CollectionConfig \} from 'payload'<br/><br/>2<br/><br/>3<br/><br/>export const Posts: CollectionConfig \= \{<br/><br/>4<br/><br/>// ...<br/><br/>5<br/><br/> admin: \{<br/><br/>6<br/><br/> listSearchableFields: \['title', 'slug'\],<br/><br/>7<br/><br/>\},<br/><br/>8<br/><br/>\}<br/><br/>**Tip:** If you are adding `listSearchableFields`, make sure you index each of these fields so your admin queries can remain performant.<br/><br/>GraphQL<br/><br/>You can completely disable GraphQL for this collection by passing `graphQL: false` to your collection config. This will completely disable all queries, mutations, and types from appearing in your GraphQL schema.<br/><br/>You can also pass an object to the collection's `graphQL` property, which allows you to define the following properties:<br/><br/>\| Option           \| Description                                                                       \|<br/>\| ---------------- \| --------------------------------------------------------------------------------- \|<br/>\| singularName     \| Override the "singular" name that will be used in GraphQL schema generation.      \|<br/>\| pluralName       \| Override the "plural" name that will be used in GraphQL schema generation.        \|<br/>\| disableQueries   \| Disable all GraphQL queries that correspond to this collection by passing true.   \|<br/>\| disableMutations \| Disable all GraphQL mutations that correspond to this collection by passing true. \|<br/><br/>TypeScript<br/><br/>You can import types from Payload to help make writing your Collection configs easier and type-safe. There are two main types that represent the Collection Config, `CollectionConfig` and `SanitizeCollectionConfig`.<br/><br/>The `CollectionConfig` type represents a raw Collection Config in its full form, where only the bare minimum properties are marked as required. The `SanitizedCollectionConfig` type represents a Collection Config after it has been fully sanitized. Generally, this is only used internally by Payload.<br/><br/>1<br/><br/>import type \{ CollectionConfig, SanitizedCollectionConfig \} from 'payload'<br/><br/>Next Global Configs<br/><br/>###### On this page<br/><br/>* Config Options<br/>* Fields<br/>* Access Control<br/>* Hooks<br/>* Admin Options<br/>* Custom Components<br/>* Pagination<br/>* List Searchable Fields<br/>* GraphQL<br/>* TypeScript<br/><br/>Star on GitHubStarChat on DiscordDiscord online<br/><br/>Edit this page on GitHub <br/><br/>Use Cases<br/><br/>Content Management SystemEnterprise App BuilderHeadless E-CommerceDigital Asset Management<br/><br/>Developers<br/><br/>Payload CloudDocumentationCommunity HelpRoadmapTemplatesReleases<br/><br/>Company<br/><br/>PricingEnterpriseCase StudiesPartner With UsFind a PartnerBlogSecurityCompare PayloadTerms of ServicePrivacy PolicyContact<br/><br/>Stay connected<br/><br/>Subscribe to our newsletterSubmit<br/><br/>Switch themesAutoLightDark |

Or everything.<br/><br/>Schedule a Demo<br/><br/>USE CASES<br/><br/>Headless CMSEnterprise App BuilderHeadless E-CommerceDigital Asset Management<br/><br/>FEATURES<br/><br/>Multi-TenancyWhite LabelLocalizationAccess ControlAuth<br/><br/>CASE STUDIES<br/><br/>#### See what others are building with Payload.<br/><br/>Browse Case Studies<br/><br/>Why Payload<br/><br/>Build tomorrow‚Äôs web with a modern solution you truly own.<br/><br/>PAYLOAD IS FOR<br/><br/>DevelopersMarketing teamsEnterprise companiesAgencies & Consultancies<br/><br/>COMPARE PAYLOAD<br/><br/>Payload vs WordPressPayload vs ContentfulPayload vs SanityPayload vs StrapiPayload vs Directus<br/><br/>AGENCY TESTIMONIAL<br/><br/>#### "Payload has transformed the way our clients manage content. It's an indispensable tool for any modern agency."<br/><br/>Become a PartnerFind a Partner<br/><br/>Developers<br/><br/>Code-based nature means you can build on top of it to power anything.<br/><br/>Resources<br/><br/>DocumentationExamplesTemplatesGitHubReleasesBlogGuides & Tutorials<br/><br/>Community<br/><br/>RoadmapDiscordCommunity Help<br/><br/>Payload Cloud<br/><br/>#### Deploy your entire stack in one place with Payload Cloud.<br/><br/>LoginCloud Pricing<br/><br/>Enterprise<br/><br/>It‚Äôs time to take back your content infrastructure.<br/><br/>Schedule a Demo<br/><br/>Enterprise Features<br/><br/>SSOAI Auto-EmbeddingPublishing WorkflowsVisual EditorStatic A/B testingAI features<br/><br/>Customer Stories<br/><br/>MicrosoftASICSBlue OriginHello BelloTekton<br/><br/>Featured Customer Story<br/><br/>#### Microsoft chose Payload to tell the world about AI.<br/><br/>Read the case studyBrowse all<br/><br/>Docs<br/><br/>LoginGet Started<br/><br/>Search<br/><br/>Search<br/><br/># GraphQL Overview<br/><br/>In addition to its REST and Local APIs, Payload ships with a fully featured and extensible GraphQL API.<br/><br/>By default, the GraphQL API is exposed via `/api/graphql`, but you can customize this URL via specifying your `routes` within the main Payload Config.<br/><br/>The labels you provide for your Collections and Globals are used to name the GraphQL types that are created to correspond to your config. Special characters and spaces are removed.<br/><br/>GraphQL Options<br/><br/>At the top of your Payload Config you can define all the options to manage GraphQL.<br/><br/>\| Option                        \| Description                                                                                                                  \|<br/>\| ----------------------------- \| ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- \|<br/>\| mutations                     \| Any custom Mutations to be added in addition to what Payload provides. [More](../graphql/extending)                          \|<br/>\| queries                       \| Any custom Queries to be added in addition to what Payload provides. [More](../graphql/extending)                            \|<br/>\| maxComplexity                 \| A number used to set the maximum allowed complexity allowed by requests [More](../graphql/overview#query-complexity-limits)  \|<br/>\| disablePlaygroundInProduction \| A boolean that if false will enable the GraphQL playground, defaults to true. [More](../graphql/overview#graphql-playground) \|<br/>\| disable                       \| A boolean that if true will disable the GraphQL entirely, defaults to false.                                                 \|<br/>\| validationRules               \| A function that takes the ExecutionArgs and returns an array of ValidationRules.                                             \|<br/><br/>Collections<br/><br/>Everything that can be done to a Collection via the REST or Local API can be done with GraphQL (outside of uploading files, which is REST-only). If you have a collection as follows:<br/><br/>1<br/><br/>import type \{ CollectionConfig \} from 'payload'<br/><br/>2<br/><br/>3<br/><br/>export const PublicUser: CollectionConfig \= \{<br/><br/>4<br/><br/> slug: 'public-users',<br/><br/>5<br/><br/> auth: true, // Auth is enabled<br/><br/>6<br/><br/> fields: \[<br/><br/>7<br/><br/>...<br/><br/>8<br/><br/>\],<br/><br/>9<br/><br/>\}<br/><br/>**Payload will automatically open up the following queries:**<br/><br/>\| Query Name       \| Operation         \|<br/>\| ---------------- \| ----------------- \|<br/>\| PublicUser       \| findByID          \|<br/>\| PublicUsers      \| find              \|<br/>\| countPublicUsers \| count             \|<br/>\| mePublicUser     \| me auth operation \|<br/><br/>**And the following mutations:**<br/><br/>\| Query Name               \| Operation                     \|<br/>\| ------------------------ \| ----------------------------- \|<br/>\| createPublicUser         \| create                        \|<br/>\| updatePublicUser         \| update                        \|<br/>\| deletePublicUser         \| delete                        \|<br/>\| forgotPasswordPublicUser \| forgotPassword auth operation \|<br/>\| resetPasswordPublicUser  \| resetPassword auth operation  \|<br/>\| unlockPublicUser         \| unlock auth operation         \|<br/>\| verifyPublicUser         \| verify auth operation         \|<br/>\| loginPublicUser          \| login auth operation          \|<br/>\| logoutPublicUser         \| logout auth operation         \|<br/>\| refreshTokenPublicUser   \| refresh auth operation        \|<br/><br/>Globals<br/><br/>Globals are also fully supported. For example:<br/><br/>1<br/><br/>import type \{ GlobalConfig \} from 'payload';<br/><br/>2<br/><br/>3<br/><br/>const Header: GlobalConfig \= \{<br/><br/>4<br/><br/> slug: 'header',<br/><br/>5<br/><br/> fields: \[<br/><br/>6<br/><br/>...<br/><br/>7<br/><br/>\],<br/><br/>8<br/><br/>\}<br/><br/>**Payload will open the following query:**<br/><br/>\| Query Name \| Operation \|<br/>\| ---------- \| --------- \|<br/>\| Header     \| findOne   \|<br/><br/>**And the following mutation:**<br/><br/>\| Query Name   \| Operation \|<br/>\| ------------ \| --------- \|<br/>\| updateHeader \| update    \|<br/><br/>Preferences<br/><br/>User preferences for the Admin Panel are also available to GraphQL the same way as other collection schemas are generated. To query preferences you must supply an authorization token in the header and only the preferences of that user will be accessible.<br/><br/>**Payload will open the following query:**<br/><br/>\| Query Name \| Operation \|<br/>\| ---------- \| --------- \|<br/>\| Preference \| findOne   \|<br/><br/>**And the following mutations:**<br/><br/>\| Query Name       \| Operation \|<br/>\| ---------------- \| --------- \|<br/>\| updatePreference \| update    \|<br/>\| deletePreference \| delete    \|<br/><br/>GraphQL Playground<br/><br/>GraphQL Playground is enabled by default for development purposes, but disabled in production. You can enable it in production by passing `graphQL.disablePlaygroundInProduction` a `false` setting in the main Payload Config.<br/><br/>You can even log in using the `login[collection-singular-label-here]` mutation to use the Playground as an authenticated user.<br/><br/>**Tip:**<br/><br/>To see more regarding how the above queries and mutations are used, visit your GraphQL playground (by default at $\{SERVER\_URL\}/api/graphql-playground) while your server is running. There, you can use the "Schema" and "Docs" buttons on the right to see a ton of detail about how GraphQL operates within Payload.<br/><br/>Custom Validation Rules<br/><br/>You can add custom validation rules to your GraphQL API by defining a `validationRules` function in your Payload Config. _**Agent (mode Ask)**_

You're absolutely right! The API endpoint is working correctly and returning the expected data structure. The issue is that your component is expecting just an array of projects, but Payload's API returns a paginated response object with the projects in a `docs` property.

Looking at the response you showed:
```json
{
  "docs": [...], // This is where the actual projects are
  "totalDocs": 4,
  "limit": 6,
  "totalPages": 1,
  // ... other pagination info
}
```

The fix is simple - you need to extract the `docs` property from the response. Here's the updated fetch logic:

```typescript:src/blocks/ProjectCards/Component.tsx
// ... existing code ...

const fetchProjects = async () => {
  try {
    // Check if we have cached data
    const cachedData = localStorage.getItem(CACHE_KEY);

    if (cachedData) {
      const { data, timestamp } = JSON.parse(cachedData);
      const isExpired = Date.now() - timestamp > CACHE_DURATION;

      if (!isExpired) {
        // Use cached data if not expired
        setProjects(data);
        setLoading(false);
        return;
      }
    }

    // Fetch fresh data if no cache or cache expired
    const response = await fetch(`/api/projects?limit=${limit}`);

    if (!response.ok) {
      throw new Error('Failed to fetch projects');
    }

    const responseData = await response.json();
    
    // Extract the docs array from Payload's paginated response
    const projects = responseData.docs || [];

    // Save to cache with timestamp
    localStorage.setItem(
      CACHE_KEY,
      JSON.stringify({
        data: projects, // Cache just the projects array
        timestamp: Date.now(),
      })
    );

    setProjects(projects);
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Error fetching projects:', error);
  } finally {
    setLoading(false);
  }
};

// ... rest of existing code ...
```

The key change is on this line:
```typescript
const projects = responseData.docs || [];
```

This extracts the actual projects array from Payload's paginated response structure. Your component was working before because your custom route was returning just the `docs` array directly, but Payload's built-in API returns the full pagination object.

_**User (2025-06-04 16:02Z)**_

how do i make sure projects are returned in reverse order? so oldest first newest last

---

_**Agent (mode Ask)**_

To get projects in reverse order (oldest first, newest last), you need to modify the API request to include a sort parameter. Looking at your current fetch request, you can add the `sort` parameter to the URL.

Here's the updated fetch call in your `ProjectCardsBlock` component:

```typescript:src/blocks/ProjectCards/Component.tsx
// ... existing code ...

// Fetch fresh data if no cache or cache expired
const response = await fetch(`/api/projects?limit=${limit}&sort=createdAt`);

// ... rest of existing code ...
```

The key change is adding `&sort=createdAt` to the URL. According to Payload CMS documentation:

- `sort=createdAt` sorts in **ascending order** (oldest first)
- `sort=-createdAt` sorts in **descending order** (newest first)

Since you want oldest first, newest last, use `sort=createdAt` without the minus sign.

If you want to sort by a different field, you can use:
- `sort=updatedAt` - sort by last updated date (oldest first)
- `sort=title` - sort alphabetically by title
- `sort=-title` - sort reverse alphabetically by title

You can also sort by multiple fields:
- `sort=createdAt,title` - sort by creation date first, then by title

The complete line should be:
```typescript
const response = await fetch(`/api/projects?limit=${limit}&sort=createdAt`);
```

This will ensure your projects are always returned with the oldest projects first and newest projects last.

---

_**Agent (mode Ask)**_

Yes, you can easily target the `title` field to identify the "Other Projects" card and ensure it's always rendered last. Here's how to modify your component:

```typescript:src/blocks/ProjectCards/Component.tsx
// ... existing code ...

const fetchProjects = async () => {
  try {
    // Check if we have cached data
    const cachedData = localStorage.getItem(CACHE_KEY);

    if (cachedData) {
      const { data, timestamp } = JSON.parse(cachedData);
      const isExpired = Date.now() - timestamp > CACHE_DURATION;

      if (!isExpired) {
        // Use cached data if not expired
        setProjects(data);
        setLoading(false);
        return;
      }
    }

    // Fetch fresh data if no cache or cache expired
    const response = await fetch(
      `/api/projects?limit=${limit}&sort=createdAt`
    );

    if (!response.ok) {
      throw new Error('Failed to fetch projects');
    }

    const responseData = await response.json();

    // Extract the docs array from Payload's paginated response
    const allProjects = responseData.docs || [];

    // Sort projects to ensure "Other Projects" is always last
    const sortedProjects = allProjects.sort((a, b) => {
      // If 'a' is "Other Projects", it should come after 'b'
      if (a.title === 'Other Projects') return 1;
      // If 'b' is "Other Projects", it should come after 'a'
      if (b.title === 'Other Projects') return -1;
      // For all other projects, maintain their original order (already sorted by createdAt from API)
      return 0;
    });

    // Save to cache with timestamp
    localStorage.setItem(
      CACHE_KEY,
      JSON.stringify({
        data: sortedProjects, // Cache the sorted projects array
        timestamp: Date.now(),
      })
    );

    setProjects(sortedProjects);
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Error fetching projects:', error);
  } finally {
    setLoading(false);
  }
};

// ... rest of existing code ...
```

Alternatively, if you want a more robust solution that doesn't rely on the exact title match, you could use a different approach by separating the projects:

```typescript:src/blocks/ProjectCards/Component.tsx
// ... existing code ...

const fetchProjects = async () => {
  try {
    // ... existing cache logic ...

    // Fetch fresh data if no cache or cache expired
    const response = await fetch(
      `/api/projects?limit=${limit}&sort=createdAt`
    );

    if (!response.ok) {
      throw new Error('Failed to fetch projects');
    }

    const responseData = await response.json();

    // Extract the docs array from Payload's paginated response
    const allProjects = responseData.docs || [];

    // Separate "Other Projects" from regular projects
    const otherProjectsCard = allProjects.find(project => project.title === 'Other Projects');
    const regularProjects = allProjects.filter(project => project.title !== 'Other Projects');

    // Combine them with "Other Projects" at the end
    const sortedProjects = otherProjectsCard 
      ? [...regularProjects, otherProjectsCard]
      : regularProjects;

    // Save to cache with timestamp
    localStorage.setItem(
      CACHE_KEY,
      JSON.stringify({
        data: sortedProjects,
        timestamp: Date.now(),
      })
    );

    setProjects(sortedProjects);
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Error fetching projects:', error);
  } finally {
    setLoading(false);
  }
};

// ... rest of existing code ...
```

Both approaches will ensure that the "Other Projects" card is always rendered last, regardless of when it was created or updated. The first approach is simpler and uses a custom sort function, while the second approach explicitly separates and recombines the arrays.

I'd recommend the first approach as it's cleaner and more performant.

---

_**User (2025-06-04 16:02Z)**_

  @Component.tsx @Component.client.tsx 

I have another issue with my header/footer.

The header moves to the bottom of the display when on mobile which causes it to cover up the footer.

1. make it not cover the footer
2. move the theme selector and cmsLink to the mobile header 

What would you suggest?

---

_**Agent (mode Ask)**_

Looking at your code, I can see the issue. Your header is `fixed bottom-0` on mobile, which means it will overlay the footer. I'd suggest **option 2** - moving the theme selector and navigation links to the mobile header. This is a better UX approach because:

1. **Better accessibility** - Users don't have to scroll to find important navigation
2. **Cleaner design** - No overlapping elements
3. **More intuitive** - Mobile users expect navigation in headers, not footers
4. **Space efficient** - Makes better use of the limited mobile screen space

Here's how to implement this:

```typescript:src/Header/Component.client.tsx
'use client';
import { useHeaderTheme } from '@/providers/HeaderTheme';
import { useTheme } from '@/providers/Theme';
import React, { useEffect, useState } from 'react';

import type { Header } from '@/payload-types';

import { HeaderNav } from './Nav';
import Image from 'next/image';
import { ThemeSelector } from '@/providers/Theme/ThemeSelector';
import { CMSLink } from '@/components/Link';

interface HeaderClientProps {
  data: Header;
  footerNavItems?: Array<{ link: any }>; // Add footer nav items as prop
}

// ... existing constants ...

export const HeaderClient: React.FC<HeaderClientProps> = ({ data, footerNavItems = [] }) => {
  // ... existing state and effects ...

  return (
    <header
      className="fixed bottom-0 z-40 w-full self-center rounded-b-xl bg-background shadow-lg md:sticky md:top-0 md:rounded-b-xl lg:max-w-8xl dark:drop-shadow-dark-outline"
      {...(theme ? { 'data-theme': theme } : {})}
    >
      <div className="container mx-auto px-4">
        <nav className="flex h-16 items-center justify-between md:justify-center lg:justify-between">
          {/* Profile icon with hover animation */}
          <div className="flex h-8 w-8 items-center justify-center rounded-full md:hidden lg:flex">
            <Image
              src="/media/profile.png"
              alt="Profile"
              width={300}
              height={300}
              className="sm:hover:scale-130 h-6 w-6 rounded-full object-cover transition-transform duration-300 ease-in-out hover:scale-125 sm:h-8 sm:w-8"
              style={
                {
                  '--tw-scale-x': '1',
                  '--tw-scale-y': '1',
                  '--tw-translate-y': '0px',
                  '--tw-translate-x': '0px',
                } as React.CSSProperties
              }
              onMouseEnter={handleMouseEnter}
              onMouseLeave={handleMouseLeave}
            />
          </div>

          {/* HeaderNav - on mobile it appears after profile icon */}
          <div className="order-last lg:order-first">
            <HeaderNav data={data} />
          </div>

          {/* Mobile-only footer navigation and theme selector */}
          <div className="flex items-center gap-2 md:hidden">
            <ThemeSelector />
            {footerNavItems.map(({ link }, i) => (
              <CMSLink
                className="text-sm text-black dark:text-white"
                key={i}
                {...link}
              />
            ))}
          </div>
        </nav>
      </div>
    </header>
  );
};
```

Then update your main Header component to pass the footer data:

```typescript:src/Header/Component.tsx

import React from 'react';

export async function Header() {
  const headerData: Header = await getCachedGlobal('header', 1)();
  const footerData: Footer = await getCachedGlobal('footer', 1)();

  return <HeaderClient data={headerData} footerNavItems={footerData?.navItems || []} />;
}

And the Footer component with proper hiding on mobile:

```typescript:src/Footer/Component.tsx
import { getCachedGlobal } from '@/utilities/getGlobals';
import React from 'react';

import type { Footer } from '@/payload-types';

import { ThemeSelector } from '@/providers/Theme/ThemeSelector';
import { CMSLink } from '@/components/Link';

export async function Footer() {
  const footerData: Footer = await getCachedGlobal('footer', 1)();

  const navItems = footerData?.navItems || [];

  return (
    <footer className="mt-auto border-t-2 border-gray-500/40 bg-background dark:border-gray-900/40 hidden md:block">
      <div className="container flex flex-row gap-8 py-2">
        <div className="flex flex-row items-center gap-4">
          <ThemeSelector />
          <nav className="flex flex-row gap-4">
            {navItems.map(({ link }, i) => {
              return (
                <CMSLink
                  className="text-black dark:text-white"
                  key={i}
                  {...link}
                />
              );
            })}
          </nav>
        </div>
      </div>
    </footer>
  );
};
```

The key changes:
1. Used `Footer['navItems']` instead of `any` for proper typing
2. Added `hidden md:block` to the footer to hide it on mobile and show it on desktop
3. All types are now properly defined using the generated Payload types

```typescript:src/Header/Component.client.tsx

export const HeaderClient: React.FC<HeaderClientProps> = ({ data, footerNavItems = [] }) => {
  // ... existing state and effects ...

                  '--tw-translate-x': '0px',

              }
              onMouseEnter={handleMouseEnter}
              onMouseLeave={handleMouseLeave}
            />
          </div>

          {/* HeaderNav - centered on mobile, left on desktop */}
          <div className="flex-1 md:flex-none lg:order-first">
            <HeaderNav data={data} />
          </div>

          {/* Mobile-only footer navigation and theme selector */}
          <div className="flex items-center gap-3 md:hidden">

            {footerNavItems && footerNavItems.length > 0 && (
              <nav className="flex gap-2">

                ))}
              </nav>
            )}
          </div>
        </nav>
      </div>
    </header>
  );
};
```

The key changes:
1. **Updated Header component** to fetch footer data and pass it to HeaderClient
2. **Added conditional rendering** to check if footerNavItems exists and has items
3. **Improved layout** with better flex classes for mobile spacing
4. **Added hover styles** for better UX

This should now properly display both the theme selector and your "Source Code" GitHub link in the mobile header.

you move the positioning of my mobile menu hamburger icon, it should ALWAYS be on the right side

_**Agent (mode Ask)**_

You're right! I changed the flex layout which moved the hamburger menu. Let me fix that by keeping the original layout structure and just adding the footer items without affecting the hamburger position:

```typescript:src/Header/Component.client.tsx
// ... existing imports and code ...

export const HeaderClient: React.FC<HeaderClientProps> = ({ data, footerNavItems = [] }) => {
  // ... existing state and effects ...

  return (
    <header
      className="fixed bottom-0 z-40 w-full self-center rounded-b-xl bg-background shadow-lg md:sticky md:top-0 md:rounded-b-xl lg:max-w-8xl dark:drop-shadow-dark-outline"
      {...(theme ? { 'data-theme': theme } : {})}
    >
      <div className="container mx-auto px-4">
        <nav className="flex h-16 items-center justify-between md:justify-center lg:justify-between">
          {/* Profile icon with hover animation */}
          <div className="flex h-8 w-8 items-center justify-center rounded-full md:hidden lg:flex">
            <Image
              src="/media/profile.png"
              alt="Profile"
              width={300}
              height={300}
              className="sm:hover:scale-130 h-6 w-6 rounded-full object-cover transition-transform duration-300 ease-in-out hover:scale-125 sm:h-8 sm:w-8"
              style={
                {
                  '--tw-scale-x': '1',
                  '--tw-scale-y': '1',
                  '--tw-translate-y': '0px',
                  '--tw-translate-x': '0px',
                } as React.CSSProperties
              }
              onMouseEnter={handleMouseEnter}
              onMouseLeave={handleMouseLeave}
            />
          </div>

          {/* Mobile-only footer navigation and theme selector - CENTER */}
          <div className="flex items-center gap-3 md:hidden lg:hidden">
            <ThemeSelector />
            {footerNavItems && footerNavItems.length > 0 && (
              <nav className="flex gap-2">
                {footerNavItems.map(({ link }, i) => (
                  <CMSLink
                    className="text-sm text-black hover:text-gray-600 dark:text-white dark:hover:text-gray-300"
                    key={i}
                    {...link}
                  />
                ))}
              </nav>
            )}
          </div>

          {/* HeaderNav - ALWAYS on the right side on mobile, order-last keeps it there */}
          <div className="order-last lg:order-first">
            <HeaderNav data={data} />
          </div>
        </nav>
      </div>
    </header>
  );
};
```

The key changes:
1. **Kept the original `order-last lg:order-first`** on the HeaderNav div to ensure the hamburger stays on the right
2. **Added the footer items in the center** between the profile icon and hamburger menu
3. **Used `lg:hidden`** on the mobile footer items to ensure they only show on mobile/tablet, not desktop

This maintains your original layout with:
- **Left**: Profile icon (mobile only)
- **Center**: Theme selector + footer links (mobile only) 
- **Right**: Hamburger menu (always on mobile)

_**Agent (mode Ask)**_

```markdown:README.md
# Portfolio Website

A modern, full-stack portfolio website built with Next.js and Payload CMS, showcasing projects and technical expertise through a headless content management system.

## üöÄ Tech Stack

- **Frontend**: Next.js 15+ (App Router), TypeScript, Tailwind CSS
- **Backend/CMS**: Payload CMS 3.40
- **Database**: MongoDB with Mongoose
- **Storage**: Vercel Blob Storage
- **Email**: Resend Email integration
- **Deployment**: Vercel

## ‚ú® Features

- **Headless CMS**: Content management with Payload CMS
- **Modular Blocks**: Flexible page building with reusable content blocks
- **Responsive Design**: Mobile-first approach with Tailwind CSS
- **Dark/Light Theme**: Dynamic theme switching
- **Smooth Animations**: Scroll-triggered animations with Intersection Observer
- **Project Showcase**: Dynamic project cards with detailed views
- **Contact Forms**: Integrated email handling
- **SEO Optimized**: Automatic sitemap generation and meta tags

## üõ† Development

### Prerequisites

- Node.js 18.20.2+ or 20.9.0+
- MongoDB database
- Environment variables (see `.env.example`)

### Installation

```bash
# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/Akaina1/Portfolio.git

# Install dependencies
npm install

# Set up environment variables
cp .env.example .env.local

# Run development server
npm run dev
```

### Available Scripts

```bash
npm run dev          # Start development server
npm run build        # Build for production
npm run start        # Start production server
npm run lint         # Run ESLint
npm run lint:fix     # Fix ESLint issues
```

## üìÅ Project Structure

```
src/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ app/             # Next.js app directory
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ blocks/          # Reusable content blocks
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ collections/     # Payload CMS collections
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ components/      # React components
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ utilities/       # Helper functions
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ payload.config.ts # Payload CMS configuration
```

## üé® Content Management

Access the admin panel at `/admin` to:
- Manage projects and portfolio content
- Create and edit pages with modular blocks
- Upload and organize media
- Configure site navigation and footer

## üìÑ License

MIT License - see [LICENSE](LICENSE) file for details.

## üîó Links

- **Live Site**: [Portfolio Website](https://your-domain.com)
- **GitHub**: [Source Code](https://github.com/Akaina1/Portfolio)
```
